actions-list.header: On agreeing to the Ogles amendment (A014) Roll Call 307
actions-list.actionItem: Recorded vote pending.
On agreeing to the Davidson amendment; Failed by recorded vote: (Roll no. 306).
On agreeing to the Greene (GA) amendment; Failed by recorded vote: (Roll no. 305).
On agreeing to the Gaetz amendment; Failed by recorded vote: (Roll no. 304).
On agreeing to the Greene (GA) amendment; Failed by recorded vote: (Roll no. 303).
On agreeing to the Norman amendment; Agreed to by recorded vote: (Roll no. 302).
On agreeing to the Rosendale amendment; Agreed to by recorded vote: (Roll no. 301).
On agreeing to the Jackson (TX) amendment; Agreed to by recorded vote: (Roll no. 300).
On agreeing to the Tlaib amendment; Failed by recorded vote: (Roll no. 299).
On agreeing to the Blumenauer amendment; Failed by recorded vote: (Roll no. 298).
The Chair announced the unfinished business was the question on agreeing to the amendments to H.R. 2670 which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.

At the conclusion of debate on the Roy amendment No. 31, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the noes had prevailed. Mr. Roy demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 583, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Roy amendment No. 31.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Roy,  numbered 31 printed in House Report 118-143 to prohibit funds authorized for DoDEA from being used to promote that idea that, 1) Any race is inherently superior or inferior to any other race, color, or national origin. 2) The US is a fundamentally racist country. 3) The Declaration of Independence or the US Constitution are racist documents, 4) An individual's moral character or worth is determined by the individual's race, color, or national origin. 5) An individual, by virtue of the individual's race, is inherently racist or oppressive, whether consciously or unconsciously. 6) An individual, because of the individuals race, bears responsibility for the actions committed by other members of the individuals race, color, or national origin.

At the conclusion of debate on the Roy amendment No. 30, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the noes had prevailed. Mr. Roy demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 583, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Roy amendment No. 30.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Roy,  numbered 30 printed in House Report 118-143 to amend Section 904 to prohibit federal funds from being used to establish a position within the Department of Defense for anything similar to Chief Diversity Officers or Senior Advisors for Diversity and Inclusion.

At the conclusion of debate on the Tlaib amendment No. 28, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the noes had prevailed. Ms. Tlaib demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 583, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Tlaib amendment No. 28.

An amendment, offered by Ms. Tlaib,  numbered 28 printed in House Report 118-143 to strike the prohibition on the reduction of the total number of nuclear armed Intercontinental Ballistic Missiles (ICBMs) deployed in the United States in Sec. 1638.

At the conclusion of debate on the Blumenauer amendment No. 27, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the noes had prevailed. Mr. Blumenauer demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 583, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Blumenauer amendment No. 27.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Blumenauer,  numbered 27 printed in House Report 118-143 to strike section 1639 and to prohibit the use of funds for the sustainment of the B83-1 bomb.

At the conclusion of debate on the Ogles amendment No. 25, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the noes had prevailed. Mr. Ogles demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 583, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Ogles amendment No. 25.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Ogles,  numbered 25 printed in House Report 118-143 to strike section 1224 of the bill, which extends lend-lease authority to Ukraine.

At the conclusion of debate on the Davidson amendment No. 24, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the noes had prevailed. Mr. Davidson demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 583, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Davidson amendment No. 24.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Davidson,  numbered 24 printed in House Report 118-143 to require the President, in coordination with the Secretary of Defense and Secretary of State, to develop and submit a report to Congress that contains a strategy for U.S. involvement in Ukraine.
Subsequently, the Committee of the Whole resumed it's sitting.
The Committee of the Whole rose informally to receive a message from the President.

At the conclusion of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 23, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the noes had prevailed. Ms. Greene (GA) demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 583, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 23.
An amendment, offered by Ms. Greene (GA),  numbered 23 printed in House Report 118-143 to strike the creation of a Center of Excellence in Ukraine.

At the conclusion of debate on the Gaetz amendment No. 22, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the noes had prevailed. Mr. Gaetz demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 583, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Gaetz amendment No. 22.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Gaetz,  numbered 22 printed in House Report 118-142 to prohibit security assistance for Ukraine.

At the conclusion of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 21, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the noes had prevailed. Mr. Gaetz demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 583, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 21.
An amendment, offered by Ms. Greene (GA),  numbered 21 printed in House Report 118-142 to strike $300 million of Ukraine funding.

At conclusion of debate on the Norman (SC) amendment No. 20, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Smith (WA) demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 583, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Norman (SC) amendment No. 20.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Norman,  numbered 20 printed in House Report 118-142 to prohibit provision of gender transition procedures, including surgery or medication, through the Exceptional Family Member Program.

At conclusion of debate on the Rosendale amendment No. 10, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Ms. Jacobs demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 583, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Rosendale amendment No. 10.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Rosendale,  numbered 10 printed in House Report 118-142 to prohibit TRICARE from covering and the Department of Defense from furnishing sex reassignment surgeries and gender hormone treatments for transgender individuals.

At conclusion of debate on the Jackson (TX) amendment No. 5, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Ms. Sherrill demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 583, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Jackson (TX) amendment No. 5.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Jackson (TX),  numbered 5 printed in House Report 118-142 to prohibit the Secretary of Defense from paying for or reimbursing expenses relating to abortion services.
On agreeing to the Luna amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 583, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Luna amendment No. 1.

An amendment, offered by Mrs. Luna,  numbered 1 printed in House Report 118-142 to prohibit any form of support or direct involvement by federal agencies in research that is conducted by the Chinese government, the Chinese Communist Party, or any of their affiliated agents, intstruments, or entities.
House resolved itself into the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union pursuant to H. Res. 583 and Rule XVIII.

Rule provides for consideration of H.R. 2670. The resolution provides for further consideration of H.R. 2670 under a structured rule. The resolution makes in order only those further amendments printed in House Report 118-142. One motion to recommit provided.

Considered under the provisions of rule H. Res. 583. H.R. 2670 — "To authorize appropriations for fiscal year 2024 for military activities of the Department of Defense and for military construction, and for defense activities of the Department of Energy, to prescribe military personnel strengths for such fiscal year, and for other purposes."
Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union rises leaving H.R. 2670 as unfinished business.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the Rogers (AL) amendments; Agreed to by recorded vote: 399
actions-list.actionItem: 31 (Roll no. 297).

The Chair announced that the unfinished business is the question on agreeing to the Rogers (AL) en bloc amendment No. 5, which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House resolved into Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union for further consideration.

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 2670 — "To authorize appropriations for fiscal year 2024 for military activities of the Department of Defense and for military construction, and for defense activities of the Department of Energy, to prescribe military personnel strengths for such fiscal year, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by recorded vote: 220
On ordering the previous question Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 214

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H. Res. 583 — "Providing for further consideration of the bill (H.R. 2670) to authorize appropriations for fiscal year 2024 for military activities of the Department of Defense and for military construction, and for defense activities of the Department of Energy, to prescribe military personnel strengths for such fiscal year, and for other purposes."

The Chair announced the unfinished business was the question on ordering the previous question on H. Res. 583, and agreeing to the resolution if ordered, which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of July 13.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess for a period of less than 15 minutes.

actions-list.header: The Speaker laid before the House a message from the President transmitting a notification stating that the national emergency with respect to hostage-taking and the wrongful detention of United States nationals abroad declared in Executive Order 14078 of July 19, 2022, is to continue in effect beyond July 19, 2023
actions-list.actionItem: referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs and ordered to be printed (H. Doc. 118-52).

The House received a message from the Acting Clerk. Pursuant to the permission granted in Clause 2(h) of Rule II of the Rules of the U.S. House of Represenatives, the Acting Clerk transmitted a sealed envlope received from the White House on July 12, 2023, at 4:14 p.m., said to contain a message from the President regarding the Continuation of the National Emergency with Respect to Hostage-Taking and Wrongful Detention of United States Nationals Abroad.

At the conclusion of debate on H. Res. 583, the Chair put the question on ordering the previous question and by voice announced the ayes had prevailed. Mr. McGovern demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 583.

Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 583 — "Providing for further consideration of the bill (H.R. 2670) to authorize appropriations for fiscal year 2024 for military activities of the Department of Defense and for military construction, and for defense activities of the Department of Energy, to prescribe military personnel strengths for such fiscal year, and for other purposes."
The House proceeded with one minute speeches, which by direction of the Chair, would be limited to 15 per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Ms. Tokuda to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of July 13.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 12:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 12:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable John S. Duarte to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
